description:
Attention McGill students! 📢

The Marvin Duchow Music Library is hiring a Student Library Services Assistant for the Winter 2025 term. Go to myFuture for more information and to apply.

Deadline to submit applications is November 28, 2024

The Music Library will be hosting a book launch on Friday, November 29, from 5:30pm to 7:30pm, to celebrate the publication of Between Composers: The Letters of Norma Beecroft and Harry Somers (McGill-Queen’s University Press, 2024) by Prof. Brian Cherney.

For details and to register for the event, see the link in bio 👆

In the fall of 1959 Norma Beecroft, a twenty-five-year-old composition student, left her home in Toronto and travelled to Rome to study with the eminent Italian composer Goffredo Petrassi. She left behind her lover and mentor, the thirty-four-year-old Harry Somers, by then recognized as one of Canada’s leading young composers. For the next five-and-a-half months they wrote each other almost every day. Somers soon came to realize that he wanted Beecroft to give up her studies and return to Toronto to marry him. Despite this pressure, however, she ultimately chose to remain in Italy to study and compose, thus rejecting a conventional woman’s role. Their intense and intimate correspondence documents lives lived apart but shared on the page, until the relationship ended abruptly in February 1960. As well, the letters show both composers at pivotal moments in their careers, working on their own creative projects and experiencing the music and culture in their respective environments. Beyond illuminating the evolution of their personal relationship, these wide-ranging letters not only provide much insight into the state of contemporary music in both Europe and Canada, but also evoke for the reader the general state of Canadian arts and culture in the late 1950s.

Please join us in celebrating the publication of Between Composers on November 29. Professor Cherney will speak about and read from his new book.

The Music Library will be hosting a book launch on Friday, November 22, from 5:30 to 7:30pm, to celebrate the new publication of Cadence: A Study of Closure in Tonal Music (Oxford University Press, 2024) by William Caplin, Distinguished James McGill Professor Emeritus. 

For details and to register for the event, see the link in bio 👆
 
Cadence is a comprehensive examination of how formal units in European art music of the tonal era achieve closure. Rooted in Caplin's broader “theory of formal functions,” the book develops concepts of cadence for music of the high classical style and then extends these ideas to gauge cadential practice in earlier and later style periods. Throughout the study, various manifestations of cadence are defined in terms of their harmonic-melodic morphology as well as their formal function. The book introduces a host of theoretical concepts illustrated by more than seven hundred musical examples, all of which contain extensive analytical annotations of harmony, melody, cadence, and form. 
 
Please join us in celebrating the publication of Cadence: A Study of Closure in Tonal Music. Professor Caplin will speak about his new book and copies will be available for purchase at a discount.

If you're feeling defeated after last night, here are a few books that remind us about the power of music to shape our society and our communities. Music can change the world, y'all.

To see the full list of books about music, politics, and democracy from the catalogue (published in the last five years), see the link in bio 👆

Featured books:
Adlington, Robert. 2024. Musical Models of Democracy. Oxford University Press.

Adlington, Robert, and Esteban Buch, eds. 2021. Finding Democracy in Music. Routledge, Taylor & Francis Group. 

Fischlin, Daniel, Ajay Heble, eds. 2020. Rebel Musics, Volume 2 Human Rights, Resistant Sounds, and the Politics of Music Making. Black Rose Books.

Franklin, M. I. 2024. Change the Record - Punk Women Music Politics. 1st ed. Transcript Verlag.

Rabaka, Reiland. 2022. Black Power Music! Protest Songs, Message Music, and the Black Power Movement. Routledge.

Schreiber, Brad. 2020. Music Is Power: Popular Songs, Social Justice and the Will to Change. Rutgers University Press.

Shao, Oliver Y. 2023. Composing Aid: Music, Refugees, and Humanitarian Politics. Indiana University Press.

Stokes, Martin. 2023. Music and Citizenship. Oxford University Press.
